cards.title: Definition - Linear Combination
cards.frontText: State the definition of a linear combination of a list of vectors \(v_1, ..., v_m \in V\).
cards.backText: A linear combination of vectors \(v_1, ..., v_m \in V\) is any vector of the form \(\lambda_1v_1 + ... + \lambda_mv_m\) with \(\lambda_1, ..., \lambda_m \in F\).

cards.title: Definition - Span
cards.frontText: State the definition of the span of a list of vectors \(v_1, ..., v_m \in V\).
cards.backText: The span of \(v_1, ..., v_m \in V\) is the set of all linear combinations of \(v_1, ..., v_m\). I.e., $$span(v_1, ..., v_m) = \{\lambda_1v_1 + ... + \lambda_mv_m : \lambda_1, ..., \lambda_m \in F\}$$. The span of the empty list \(()\) is defined to be \(\{0\}\).

cards.title: Proof - The Span of a List of Vectors is the Smallest Containing Subspace
cards.frontText: Prove that the span of vectors \(v_1, ..., v_m \in V\) is the smallest subspace of \(V\) containing \(v_1, ..., v_m\).
cards.backText:
First, we prove that the span of \(v_1, ..., v_m\) defines a subspace. \(span(v_1, ..., v_m)\) contains the additive identity: \(0v_1 + ... + 0v_m = 0\), which is the additive identity. \(span(v_1, ..., v_m)\) is closed under addition: take arbitrary \(x = x_1v_1 + ... + x_mv_m\) and \(y = y_1v_1 + ... + y_mv_m\), both in \(span(v_1, ..., v_m)\). $$x + y = x_1v_1 + ... + x_mv_m + y_1v_1 + ... + y_mv_m$$. By commutativity and distributivity, this can be expressed as $$(x_1 + y_1)v_1 + ... + (x_m + y_m)v_m$$. By the closure of \(F\) under addition, each \(x_k + y_k \in F\). Therefore, \(x + y \in span(v_1, ..., v_m)\). Closure of \(span(v_1, ..., v_m)\) under scalar multiplication: take arbitrary \(x = \lambda_1v_1 + ... + \lambda_mv_m \in span(v_1, ..., v_m)\). Take arbitrary \(\mu \in F\). Then $$\mu x = \mu(\lambda_1v_1 + ... + \lambda_mv_m) = \mu \lambda_1v_1 + ... + \mu \lambda_mv_m$$ by distributivity. Since \(F\) is closed under scalar multiplication, each $\mu \lambda_k \in F$, and this \(\mu x \in span(v_1, ..., v_m)\). This proves that \(span(v_1, ..., v_m)\) is a subspace of \(V\).
Now we show that \(span(v_1, ..., v_m)\) contains \(v_1, ..., v_m\). Take arbitrary \(k \in \{1, ..., m\}\). Form a linear combination \(\lambda_1v_1 + ... + \lambda_mv_m\) with \(\lambda_k = 1\) and \(\lambda_j = 0\) for \(j \neq k\). Therefore, \(\lambda_1v_1 + ... + \lambda_mv_m = v_k\). Thus, each \(v_k\) is present within \(span(v_1, ..., v_m)\).
Finally, we can prove that any set containing each \(v_1, ..., v_m\) must contain \(span(v_1, ..., v_m)\): assume that \(U\) is a subspace of \(V\), containing each of \(v_1, ..., v_m\). By the closure of \(U\) under addition and scalar multiplication \(\lambda_1 v_1 + ... + \lambda_m v_m \in U\). Therefore, \(U\) contains \(span(v_1, ..., v_m)\).
Thus, we have shown that any subspace containing \(v_1, ..., v_m\) must contain \(span(v_1, ..., v_m)\), and thus \(span(v_1, ..., v_m)\) is the smallest subspace containing \(v_1, ..., v_m\).

cards.title: Proof - Span of \(F^n\)
cards.backText:
To show that \(span((1, 0, ..., 0), (0, 1, ..., 0), ..., (0, 0, ..., 1)) = F^n\), we need to show that \(span(v_1, ..., v_m) \subseteq F^n\) and that \(F^n \subseteq span(v_1, ..., v_m)\).
\(span(v_1, ..., v_m) \subseteq F^n\): take arbitrary \(\lambda_1 (1, 0, ..., 0) + \lambda_2 (0, 1, ..., 0) + ... + \lambda_m (0, 0, ..., 1) = (\lambda_1, \lambda_2, ..., \lambda_m) \in F\), by definition of \(F^n\). Thus \(span(v_1, ..., v_m) \subseteq F^n\).
Take arbitrary \((x_1, x_2, ..., x_n) \in F^n\), then \((x_1, x_2, ..., x_n) = x_1 (1, 0, ..., 0) + x_2 (0, 1, ..., 0) + ... + x_n (0, 0, ..., 1) \in span(v_1, ..., v_m)\). Therefore, \(F^n \subseteq span(x_1, ..., x_n).
By definition, \(span(v_1, ..., v_n) = F^n\).\)

cards.title: Definition - Finite-Dimensional Vector Space
cards.frontText: State the definition of a finite-dimensional vector space.
cards.backText: A vector space is finite dimensional if some list of vectors in it spans the space. Recall that a list must have a finite length, so a vector space is finite dimensional if it is spanned by a finite number of vectors in it.

cards.title: Definition - Polynomial, \(\mathcal{P}(F)\)
cards.frontText: State the definition of a polynomial and give the definition of \(\mathcal{P}(F)\).
cards.backText: A function \(p : F \rightarrow F\) is called a polynomial with coefficients in \(F\) if there exists \(\lambda_0, ..., \lambda_m \in F\) such that \(p(z) = \lambda_0 + \lambda_1z + \lambda_2z^2 + ... + \lambda_mz^m\), for all \(z \in F\). We define \(\mathcal{P}(F)\) as the set of all polynomials with coefficients in \(F\).

cards.title: Proof - \(\mathcal{P}(F)\) Forms a Vector Space Over \(F\)
cards.frontText: Prove that \(\mathcal{P}(F)\) defines a vector space over \(F\).
cards.backText:
Closure under addition: take arbitrary \(x = x_0 + x_1z + x_2z^2 + ... + x_nz^n\) and \(y = y_0 + y_1z + y_2z^2 + ... + y_mz^m\). By commutativity and distributivity, \(x + y = (x_0 + y_0) + (x_1 + y_1)z + (x_2 + y_2)z^2 + ... + (x_n + y_n)z^n + ... + (x_m)z^m\). Note that we have assumed here that \(n < m\), but the proof for cases \(n = m\) and \(n > m\) are similar. Since \(F\) is closed under addition, each \(x_k + y_k \in F\). Therefore \(x + y \in \mathcal{P}(F)\).
Closure under scalar multiplication: take arbitrary \(x(z) = x_0 + x_1z + x_2z^2 + ... + x_nz^n \in \mathcal{P}(z)\), and arbitrary \(\lambda \in F\). \(\lambda x(z) = \lambda (x_0 + x_1 z + x_2 z^2 + ... + x_n z^n) = \lambda x_0 + \lambda x_1 z + \lambda x_2 z^2 + ... + \lambda x_n z^n\). By the closure of \(F\) under scalar multiplication \(\lambda x_k \in F\). Therefore, \(\lambda x \in \mathcal{P}(z)\).
Commutativity, associativity, distributivity: these follow from the commutativity, associativity and distributivity of \(F\).
Additive identity: the function \(0(x) = 0\) is the additive identity of \(\mathcal{P}(F)\). It can be thought of as the polynomial \(\lambda_0 + \lambda_1 z + ... + \lambda_n z^n\) where each \(\lambda_i = 0\).
Multiplicative identity: the multiplicative identity \(1 \in F\) is the multiplicative identity of \(\mathcal{P}(F)\). This is because, for example, \(1 \times (\lambda_0 + \lambda_1z + ... + \lambda_nz^n) = (1 \times \lambda_0 + 1 \times \lambda_1 z + ... + 1 \times \lambda_n z^n) = \lambda_0 + \lambda_1 z + ... + \lambda_n z^n\)
Additive inverse: take arbitrary \(\lambda_0 + \lambda_1 z + ... + \lambda_n z^n\), then, for each \(\lambda_k\), we take the additive inverse, as defined by \(F\), \(-\lambda_k\). The polynomial \(-\lambda_0 + -\lambda_1 z + -\lambda_2 z^2 + ... + -\lambda_n z^n\) is then the additive inverse, since \((\lambda_0 + -\lambda_0) + (\lambda_1 + -\lambda_1)z + ... + (\lambda_n + -\lambda_n)z^n \).

cards.title: Definition - Degree of a Polynomial
cards.frontText: State the definition of the degree of a polynomial.
cards.backText: A polynomial \(p \in \mathcal{P}(F)\) has degree \(m\) if there exists scalars \(a_0, a_1, ..., a_m \in F) with \(a_m \neq 0\) such that for every \(z \in F), we have \(p(z) = a_0 + a_1z + ... + a_mz^m\). The polynomial that is identically \(0\) (i.e. \(p(x) = 0\) for all \(x \in F\)) is said to have degree \(-\infty\).

cards.title: Definition - \(\mathcal{P}_m(F)\)
cards.backText: \(\mathcal{P}_m(F)\) denotes the set of all polynomials with coefficients in \(F\) that have degree \(m\) or less.

cards.title: Proof - \(\mathcal{P}_m(F)\) is a Finite-Dimensional Vector Space
cards.frontText: Prove that \(\mathcal{P}_m(F)\) is a finite-dimensional vector space.
cards.backText: \(\mathcal{P}_m{F}\) is spanned by \(1, z, z^2, ..., z^m\). Since this is a list of vectors (with finite length), \(\mathcal{P}_m(F)\) is a finite-dimensional vector space.

cards.title: Definition - Infinite-Dimensional Vector Space
cards.frontText: State the definition of an infinite dimensional vector space.
cards.backText: An infinite-dimensional vector space is a vector space that is not finite dimensional.

cards.title: Proof - \(\mathcal{P}(F)\) is Infinite-Dimensional
cards.backText: Assume, towards a contradiction, that \(\mathcal{P}(F)\) is a finite dimensional vector space. Therefore, it can be represented as the span of vectors \(p_1, ..., p_m \in \mathcal{P}(F)\). Since each of \(p_1, ..., p_m\) are polynomials, they each have degree \(d_i\). Take the maximum of these degrees, \(d_{max}\). Thus, every polynomial in \(span(p_1, ..., p_m)\) has at most degree \(d_{max}\). Then consider the polynomial \(x^{d_{max} + 1} \in \mathcal{P}(F)\). This is not in the span of \(p_1, ..., p_n\) but is in \(\mathcal{P}(F)\). This gives a contradiction. Thus, \(\mathca{P}(F)\) is infinite dimensional.

cards.title: Definition - Linear Independence of a List of Vectors
cards.frontText: State what it means for a list of vectors \(v_1, ..., v_m\) to be linearly independent.
cards.backText: If \(v_1, ..., v_m\) are linearly independent, then the only solution to \(\lambda_1 v_1 + ... + \lambda_m v_m = 0\) is the trivial solution \(\lanbda_1 = ... = \lambda_m = 0\).

cards.title: Proof - Linear Independent and Span
cards.frontText: Prove that a list of vectors \(v_1, ..., v_m\) is linearly independent if and only if every vector in \(span(v_1, ..., v_m)\) has only one representation.
cards.backText:
First, we will show that if a list of vectors is linearly independent, then every vector in their span has only one representation: assume that \(v_1, ..., v_m\) are linearly independent. Take arbitrary \(v \in span(v_1, ..., v_m)\). Suppose \(v = x_1v_1 + ... + x_mv_m = y_1v_1 + ... + y_mv_m\). Thus, \(0 = (x_1v_1 + ... + x_mv_m) - (y_1v_1 + ... + y_mv_m)\). By commutativity and distributivity, we have that \(0 = (x_1 - y_1)v_1 + ... + (x_m - y_m)v_m\). Since \(v_1, ..., v_m\) are linearly independent, we know that the only solution to \(\lambda_1 v_m + ... + \lambda_m v_m = 0\) is the trivial solution \(\lambda_1 = ... = \lambda_m = 0\). Thus, each \(x_i - y_i = 0\) and therefore \(x_i = y_i\). Therefore, the two linear combinations are equal, and the representation of \(v\) as a linear combination is unique.
Next, we show that if the representation of \(v\) in \(span(v_1, ..., v_m\) is unique, then \(v_1, ..., v_m\) is linearly independent: assume that \(v = x_1v_1 + ... + x_mv_m\) has a unique representation in \(span(v_1, ..., v_m)\). Assume, towards contradiction, that \(v_1, ..., v_m\) is not linearly independent. Then, there exists some \(y_1v_1 + ... + y_mv_m = 0\) with at least one \(y_k \neq 0\). Thus \(v = v + 0\) by definition of the additive identity on a vector space. Therefore, \(x_1v_1 + ... + x_mv_m = x_1v_1 + ... + x_mv_m + y_1v_1 + ... + y_mv_m = (x_1 + y_1)v_1 + ... + (x_m + y_m)v_m\). Since at least one \(y_k \neq 0\), this is not the same as \(x_1v_1 + ... + x_mv_m\) and thus \(v\) has at least two representations. This contradicts our original assumption, and thus \(v_1, ..., v_m\) is linearly independent.

cards.title: Proof - The List \((1, 0, ..., 0), (0, 1, ..., 0), (0, 0, ..., 1)\) is Linearly Independent
cards.frontText: Prove that the vectors \((1, 0, ..., 0), (0, 1, ..., 0), ..., (0, 0, ..., 1)\) are linearly independent.
cards.backText: An arbitrary linear combination \(a_1(1, 0, ..., 0) + a_2(0, 1, ..., 0) + ... + a_n(0, 0, ... 1)\) evaluates to \((a_1, a_2, ..., a_n)\). \((a_1, a_2, ..., a_n) = (0, 0, ..., 0)\) only when \(a_1 = a_2 = ... = a_n = 0\). Therefore, the only linear combination equal to \(0\) is the one where all coefficients are \(0\). Thus, the vectors are linearly independent.
